page.title: 01Mid-Northumberland Farmland
page.content: Altitude 250 - 500 feet. No village or great houses. Many hamlets, large farmsteads and isolated cottages. sparse population. almost all farmed, either grass or field crops. a few old pastures with riggs. Some sheep and cattle. Sprouting crops hard to distiguish in November - cereals or grass? many fields of a crop like young cabbages, sometimes with grass undersown. typical field boundaries are hedges, usually neat but gappy, not layered. Many small woods. No stone walls, but many stonebuilt houses. Note Longhorsley Moor in square 1 and 5; continuous almost impenetrable gorse with blackberries and wet patches. Presumably uncultivated because of tenurek, not because of soil. Few services. 'garage with servicing' for heavy commercials only. Two main roads
